author: By Nancy Hass
title: A Land Art Pioneer’s Adventures in Time and Space
description: Nearly 50 years after Charles Ross began working on “Star Axis,” the artist’s gargantuan work in the New Mexico desert is nearing completion.
content: THROUGH THE WINTER months, Charles Ross’s existence befits an established New York multimedia artist of a certain vintage: whitewashed SoHo loft with a comfortable studio in the back; a pair of sweet, shaggy dogs that he and his wife, the painter Jill O’Bryan, walk up Wooster Street in the chill, past the wrought iron storefronts that were little more than scrap metal when he first came to the city in the mid-1960s after studying math and sculpture at the University of California, Berkeley, but now are outposts of Chanel and Dior. Evenings, they may drop into a Chelsea gallery opening or two, then linger over dinner at Omen, the Japanese restaurant that’s been on Thompson Street since the ’80s, nodding to the fellow stalwarts of a downtown scene that long ago ate its young: the 92-year-old portraitist Alex Katz sharing a sake with the Abstract Expressionist David Salle, 67; the musician Laurie Anderson, 73, at the bar, her spiky hair stippled with gray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Tapestry C.E.O. Resigns, Acknowledging Past Relationship
description: Tapestry, which owns Coach and Kate Spade, had hired a law firm to look into the claim against Jide Zeitlin, one of only four Black chief executives in the Fortune 500.
content: Jide Zeitlin, the chief executive of Tapestry and one of only four Black chief executives in the Fortune 500, resigned on Tuesday and later said the unexpected move, less than a year into his tenure, was related to a past relationship. The company’s board had been made aware of a misconduct allegation involving Mr. Zeitlin and hired a law firm to investigate, according to a person familiar with the situation who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: They’re Used to Tapping. Now They’re Talking.
description: In Ayodele Casel’s video series, “Diary of a Tap Dancer, v. 6: Us,” performers talk about what’s on their minds — and dance a little, too.
content: Ayodele Casel is a top-shelf tap dancer, as generous of spirit as she is precise in technique. But years ago, she discovered that even appreciative audiences didn’t always grasp all that she was trying to communicate with her feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Shelton Clears Senate Committee, Moving Closer to Fed Board
description: President Trump’s two Federal Reserve nominees, including the hot-button pick Judy Shelton, will proceed to a vote in the full Senate.
content: WASHINGTON — Judy Shelton, an unorthodox economist with close ties to the Trump administration, moved a step closer to a seat on the Federal Reserve Board after the Senate Banking Committee voted along party lines on Tuesday to advance her nomination to the full Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nature’s Noisiest Liars Carry Secrets in Their Calls
description: Many mammals that have loud calls to deceive other animals seem to have a particular learning style in common.
content: A beast calls in the distance. Hearing a low rumble, you might imagine the source will be an unholy cross between a wild boar and a chain saw. The message is unmistakable: I’m here, I’m huge and you can either come mate with me or stay out of my way.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No, My Toddler Doesn’t Need to Learn to Code
description: Sales in educational toys are booming, but often there isn’t much weight to their claims of teaching kids science and math.
content: Botley is a small plastic robot that makes a big claim. According to toymaker Learning Resources, Botley can teach children as young as 5 how to program computer codes. In fact, “he’ll have kids coding in minutes,” the company promises on Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Nick Corasaniti and Annie Karni
title: As Trump Pushes Into Portland, His Campaign Ads Turn Darker
description: The Trump campaign is spending millions on ads that promote a dark and exaggerated portrayal of Democratic-led cities, a tactic that reinforces his “law and order’’ campaign message.
content: As President Trump deploys federal agents to Portland, Ore., and threatens to dispatch more to other cities, his re-election campaign is spending millions of dollars on several ominous television ads that promote fear and dovetail with his political message of “law and order.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Republicans Heap Criticism on Liz Cheney, Calling Her Disloyal to Trump
description: In an extraordinary intraparty airing of grievances, House Republicans lashed out at their third-ranking leader, who has sometimes broken with the president but until now escaped the ire of his closest allies.
content: In a Republican Party that prizes total loyalty to President Trump, Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, the party’s third-ranking House leader, has managed a tricky balancing act, repeatedly breaking with Mr. Trump without drawing the ire of the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: Where the Wild Things Play
description: The animal world is full of games. And tucked in among wrestling monkeys, belligerent birds and wily coyotes are lessons for us all.
content: As a sophomore in college I interned at a lab that studied dolphin behavior. The animals spent most of the year doing back flips and spraying water onto tourists at a theme park, then called Marine World Africa USA, just north of San Francisco. In their off months, they hung out with behavioral scientists who did experiments with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Britain announces raises for 900,000 public workers.
description: Nearly 900,000 public workers in Britain, including teachers, doctors and security forces, will receive raises in recognition of the “vital contribution” they have made during the coronavirus pandemic, Britain’s finance ministry announced Tuesday.

title: A Paleontologist’s Guide to Playing with Your Dinosaur Obsessed Kid
description: Paleontologists say parents should nurture children’s romance with playing with dinosaurs, for “Paleontology is the gateway to science.”
content: Every time Cheri Johnson, a senior analyst at the Chicago Transit Authority dropped off her son, Evan, at day care, he would throw a tantrum because he didn’t want her to go. Certainly, she thought, the 20-month-old would not scream all day. So one morning she spied on Evan from behind the day care’s glass door. As he was hollering and kicking his feet, she watched the other children try to console him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cities have survived pandemics before. What about this one?
description: Even as the Covid-19 death toll rises in the nation’s most dense urban cores, economists still mostly expect cities to bounce back, once there is a vaccine, a treatment or a successful strategy to contain the virus’s spread.

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Monogamous Birds of N.Y.C.’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Pigeons arrived on our fire escape, grooming one another. A couple. Affectionate. But they weren’t pigeons. There was something un-pigeonly about them. My wife called them “generic birds.” Search: “generic, monogamous birds of N.Y.C.” We discovered: “Morning doves!” No, actually: “Mourning doves,” named after their gray feathers and melancholy song. I play a recording of their plaintive call. One cocks its head in recognition. (My wife thinks he was looking at a tree.) We sit inside. They sit outside. Bonded pairs waiting out this storm, listening to ambulance sirens mix with the sound of mourning. — Scott Illingworth
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Falih Hassan
title: German Arts Advocate Kidnapped in Baghdad
description: Hella Mewis started an arts center in the Iraqi capital, and supported anti-government protesters last fall. It was not clear who abducted her.
content: BAGHDAD — Kidnappers in two vehicles seized a German arts advocate at dusk on Monday as she was leaving her office near one of Baghdad’s busiest thoroughfares, Iraqi security officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lyz Lenz
title: The Way We Used to Play
description: A mother compares her childhood freedom to her kids’ playtime, filled with structured dates, piano lessons and tablet games.
content: As kids, my seven siblings and I would run around outside under the night sky, the summer-hard soles of our bare feet the only shoes we needed, playing a game we made up called “War”.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Frieden and Cyrus Shahpar
title: We Searched for Covid-19 Data. Here’s What We Couldn’t Find.
description: Fifteen things we need to know about the coronavirus.
content: Doctors caring for patients track vital signs of temperature, blood pressure, breathing and pulse. Public health doctors fighting epidemics do something similar — they track the most important indicators of the spread of a disease and attempts to control it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: When John Lewis Cosplayed at Comic-Con as His Younger Self
description: For several years, Mr. Lewis would lead a group of children in a march across the San Diego Convention Center.
content: Representative John Lewis was looking for an orange to carry in his bag. He wanted to pack two books, a toothbrush, toothpaste, an apple and an orange inside his backpack, just like he did in 1965, when he led a vanguard of close to 600 people across the Edmund Pettus Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Accuses Hackers of Trying to Steal Coronavirus Vaccine Data for China
description: Two suspects in China targeted companies working on vaccines as part of a broader cybertheft campaign to enrich themselves and aid the Chinese government, officials said.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department accused a pair of Chinese hackers on Tuesday of targeting vaccine development on behalf of the country’s intelligence service as part of a broader yearslong campaign of global cybertheft aimed at industries such as defense contractors, high-end manufacturing and solar energy companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Climate Change Poses ‘Systemic Threat’ to the Economy, Big Investors Warn
description: Financial regulators should act to avoid economic disaster, according to a letter from pension funds and other investors representing almost $1 trillion in assets.
content: WASHINGTON — Climate change threatens to create turmoil in the financial markets, and the Federal Reserve and other regulators must act to avoid an economic disaster, according to a letter sent on Tuesday by a group of large investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Reliving ‘Private Lives,’ This Time Mostly Women’s
description: Eight short plays take cues from the 1930 Noël Coward comedy — but now the stakes are different.
content: An unlikely hodgepodge of names gets dropped in the course of Red Bull Theater’s Short New Play Festival: Virginia Woolf, Rachel Dolezal, Troilus, Cressida, Cervantes, Trump. But the name that gets dropped hardest — dropped in the sense that it all but disappears — is that of the production’s touchstone, Noël Coward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Anti-Asian Harassment Is Surging. Can Ads and Hashtags Help?
description: With more than 2,000 incidents and little action from the federal government, efforts to curtail pandemic-related racism have fallen to P.S.A.s and social media campaigns.
content: A new public service announcement makes a point that federal leaders have largely overlooked: Asian-Americans are facing a surge of harassment linked to fears about the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carrie Mae Weems
title: A More Inclusive View of MoMA’s Sculpture Garden
description: Carrie Mae Weems, known for her powerful images of African-American identity, shares a piece from her new project.
content: In this new series, The Artists, an installment of which will publish every day this week and regularly thereafter, T will highlight a recent or little-shown work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist, putting the work into context. Today, we’re looking at a piece by Carrie Mae Weems, known for her powerful images of African-American identity, whose new project, “Resist Covid Take 6!,” of which this work is a part, uses the mediums of advertising and photography to raise public awareness of Covid-19 among people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The State of Play
description: The act of playing shapes how our children see the world.
content: The first weekend of quarantine, my daughters took sidewalk chalk, made a hopscotch board in our building’s courtyard, and spent over an hour in blustery March weather jumping with glee, their hair whipping in the wind. Over the last few months, they have climbed on rocks and around jagged fences in abandoned parks; built hospitals for their ailing American Girl dolls, Blaire and Nanea, who were struck down by a mysterious illness that kept them in bed for weeks; and chucked a whole lot of rocks into a lake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler, Lara Jakes and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Request of an Ambassador: Get the British Open for Me
description: Woody Johnson, the N.F.L. owner, Trump donor and ambassador to Britain, was warned not to get involved in trying to move the tournament to a Trump resort in Scotland, but he raised the idea anyway — and he failed.
content: LONDON — The American ambassador to Britain, Robert Wood Johnson IV, told multiple colleagues in February 2018 that President Trump had asked him to see if the British government could help steer the world-famous and lucrative British Open golf tournament to the Trump Turnberry resort in Scotland, according to three people with knowledge of the episode.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dick Buerkle, Master of the Indoor Mile, Dies at 72
description: After running the 5,000 meters, Buerkle, a former Villanova walk-on, devoted himself to the mile and set a record. He regretted missing the 1980 Moscow Olympics.
content: When Dick Buerkle stood at the starting line of an indoor mile race in College Park, Md., in 1978, he was in a new phase of his career. He had been a leading middle-distance runner but had fizzled out at 5,000 meters in the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal.

content: MIAMI — Last week, a kangaroo bounded out of a backyard in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and hopped for about three blocks with the police in pursuit. title: Trial Begins in Germany Over Synagogue Attack on Yom Kippur
description: A 28-year-old racist is charged with murdering two people in an assault that raised alarm about the spread of right-wing extremism online.
content: BERLIN — A young German man charged with killing two people last fall after his plan to blast his way into a synagogue filled with Jews observing Yom Kippur failed, told a court on Tuesday that he was inspired by the white supremacist who had killed 51 worshipers at two mosques in New Zealand earlier last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Kills Broad Curbs on Military Gear for Police, Thwarting Push to Demilitarize
description: The Senate adopted a narrower proposal to limit the transfer of some military equipment to local police departments, but data shows that such restrictions have done little to reduce the flow.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday rejected a bipartisan bid to bar the Pentagon from transferring a wide range of military-grade weaponry to local police departments, effectively killing the last remaining initiative before Congress this year to address the excessive use of force in law enforcement.

title: ‘The Grand Unified Theory of Howard Bloom’ Review: A Career Rewritten
description: This documentary looks inside the life of a high-powered music publicist who became a techno-age philosopher.
content: For the past 20 years, in his second career as a best-selling author, Howard Bloom has been grappling with the big questions, all of which can be boiled down to, as he puts it here, “What does the universe want from you and me?” Bloom has, in the pre-Covid-19 world chronicled in this documentary about him, a strict routine that helps him in this discipline.

content: Michael D. Cohen says it was no secret that he was writing a jailhouse tell-all book about his former boss, President Trump. He spent hours at a stretch working on his manuscript in a prison library before he was released on furlough in May because of the coronavirus.

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Lianne La Havas Traces the Arc of a Romance
description: With supple guitar and a freewheeling voice, the English songwriter delves into matters of the heart on her self-titled third album.
content: The English songwriter Lianne La Havas has always been an outlier, working a decidedly personal amalgam of rock, pop and R&B. Her music revolves around the lithe interplay of her syncopated guitar patterns and her freewheeling voice, which leaps and curls and wriggles with an insouciant vibrato. Her guitar parts echo and rival the ambiguous, unresolved chords and supple rhythmic games of Joni Mitchell and Radiohead, while her voice moves from low, sultry insinuations to open-throated declarations.

title: This Hospital Cost $52 Million. It Treated 79 Virus Patients.

author: By Kyra Gaunt
title: The Magic of Black Girls’ Play
description: Game-songs created and passed down by Black girls are full of sophistication, power and cultural meaning.
content: Even as an only child, I learned the hidden musicianship performed by girls, for girls in the 100-year old Black neighborhood outside Washington, where I was raised. For nearly 30 years, I have written about the sophisticated culture of Black girls’ embodied musical play. From backyards to schoolyards, their game-songs predate Emancipation. Their musical blackness has much to offer once we unpack the magic in the rhythms and rhymes that animate their torsos and release their tongues with laughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Risky Play Encourages Resilience

content: As the coronavirus pandemic lingers like a hangover, many parents are still struggling to work from home and take care of their children at the same time. And for some kids, that brings a special kind of freedom: the ability to play like nobody’s watching.

description: Camila Freitas’s documentary embeds with Brazil’s Landless Workers’ Movement. And the latest “Frontline” installment examines a lack of coronavirus protections of agricultural workers.
content: LANDLESS (2019) Stream on Mubi. This summer, Mubi has been featuring movies from both up-and-coming and established Brazilian filmmakers as part of its New Brazilian Cinema series, including Camila Freitas, who directed this documentary. The film focuses on a faction of the country’s Landless Workers’ Movement, a land reform group. Freitas chronicled its activities over four years while members occupied land owned by a sugar cane processing plant that had filed for bankruptcy. As its members work the land and discuss utopian solutions for a better future, the film offers an inside look at activists that Brazil’s right-wing president, Jair Bolsonaro, has likened to a terrorist organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Whole Foods Punished Workers for Black Lives Matter Masks, Suit Says
description: Over a dozen workers at Whole Foods stores in four states claim in a class-action lawsuit that the company retaliated against them for wearing the movement’s apparel.
content: From colorful patterns and vegetable prints to SpongeBob SquarePants, creative masks have been embraced by Whole Foods employees across the country since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Officer Details Killing of Police Partner in Trial of Americans in Rome
description: The killing of Deputy Brig. Mario Cerciello Rega last year has attracted significant media attention in Italy and the United States.
content: ROME — The long-awaited appearance in court of Andrea Varriale, a crucial witness in a murder case against two young American men accused of killing an Italian law enforcement officer last year, played out in a Rome courtroom this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: New Yorkers, Voting Could Get Much Easier for You
description: The Legislature should use a rare, brief summer session to make key reforms ahead of the November elections.
content: New York’s Legislature is meeting virtually, for the most part, this week, tackling unfinished business amid the coronavirus pandemic that has wreaked havoc on the state’s health and its finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Judge Declines to Release Girl, 15, Held for Skipping Online Schoolwork
description: The Michigan teenager has been in a juvenile detention facility since May after she violated probation terms by skipping her school’s remote-learning coursework.
content: A judge on Monday denied a motion to release a Michigan teenager who has been held at a juvenile detention facility since May for not completing her online coursework, the latest development in a case that has raised a national outcry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Driver
title: Where the Sick Get Sicker and the Sane Are Driven Mad: Behind Bars
description: In “Waiting for an Echo,” Christine Montross, a psychiatrist who works in prisons, catalogs the devastating effects of incarceration on the mentally ill.
content: WAITING FOR AN ECHO The Madness of American IncarcerationBy Christine Montross
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: End of $600 Unemployment Bonus Could Push Millions Past the Brink
description: A weekly supplement has helped the jobless to pay their bills and cushioned the economy. As it expires, Congress will determine what comes next.
content: When millions of Americans began losing their jobs in March, the federal government stepped in with a life preserver: $600 a week in extra unemployment benefits to allow workers to pay rent and buy groceries, and to cushion the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Agnes Callard
title: Should We Cancel Aristotle?
description: He defended slavery and opposed the notion of human equality. But he is not our enemy.
content: The Greek philosopher Aristotle did not merely condone slavery, he defended it; he did not merely defend it, but defended it as beneficial to the slave. His view was that some people are, by nature, unable to pursue their own good, and best suited to be “living tools” for use by other people: “The slave is a part of the master, a living but separated part of his bodily frame.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Teachers Push Back on Reopening in Florida
description: Educators unions sue Ron DeSantis, and Congress debates virus aid: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Trump threatens to deploy federal troops across the country; Congress girds for another fight over coronavirus relief; and Florida teachers say, No, we won’t go. It’s Tuesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Coronavirus Threatens the Luster of Superstar Cities
description: Urban centers, with a dynamism that feeds innovation, have long been resilient. But the pandemic could drive a shift away from density.
content: Cities are remarkably resilient. They have risen from the ashes after being carpet-bombed and hit with nuclear weapons. “If you think about pandemics in the past,” noted the Princeton economist Esteban Rossi-Hansberg, “they didn’t destroy cities.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Zooming In on Bill Buford’s Latest Obsession
description: The author spent more than a decade seeking the heart of French cuisine for his new book, “Dirt.” But in quarantine, he just wants to make the perfect chicken.
content: Last month, the writer Bill Buford attempted to teach me, using Zoom, how to bone, stuff, tie and poach a chicken. It was something like one of those MasterClasses that everybody is watching these days, except that those run for 20 minutes, and my lesson lasted more than six hours. It may not have been the longest Zoom call in history, but I suspect it set a record for Zoom calls with a strong focus on boneless poultry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob E. Osterhout
title: Your Kid Doesn’t Need to Be LeBron or Serena
description: Focusing on fun and exposure to new games helps build skills and interest.
content: The sound of the basketball repeatedly smacking the parquet floor echoed across the empty community center gymnasium as I attempted to teach my 5-year-old son how to dribble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $2.7 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Rachel Shorey
title: Trump’s Tulsa Rally Drew Sparse Crowd, but It Cost $2.2 Million
description: New campaign filings show that President Trump’s campaign paid more than $2.2 million for the event, which last month had a lower-than-expected turnout that disappointed his campaign.
content: President Trump has held only one campaign rally since the pandemic swept across the country in March. It not only failed to fill the arena in Tulsa, Okla., but it was also very expensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Stewart
title: Planned Parenthood in N.Y. Disavows Margaret Sanger Over Eugenics
description: Ms. Sanger, a feminist icon and reproductive-rights pioneer, supported a discredited belief in improving the human race through selective breeding.
content: Planned Parenthood of Greater New York will remove the name of Margaret Sanger, a founder of the national organization, from its Manhattan health clinic because of her “harmful connections to the eugenics movement,” the group said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Border War in Portland
description: How can this be a job for Homeland Security?
content: Something dangerous is taking shape within the Department of Homeland Security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: When the Bake Sale Goes Global, Millions Are Raised to Fight Injustice
description: Online sales have become blockbuster events as long-sidelined pastry chefs lead a charge toward activism.
content: Like a lot of 13-year-olds, Daniella Senior loved to bake, and thought she might become a pastry chef.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Willyard
title: How Play Energizes Your Kid’s Brain
description: Scientists have long studied play to gain insights into the developing human mind.
content: Swiss psychologist Jean Piaget, one of the founding fathers of developmental psychology, spent hours each day observing his children as they grew. He recorded his observations in a raft of notebooks. Lore has it that his wife even carried a notebook on her necklace to jot down observations that Piaget himself missed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1920: Police Retaliate After Killings in Ireland
description: The town of Tuam was ransacked by the police, with buildings looted and set alight, in response to the shooting of two officers.
content: (By Special Leased Wire.) LONDON, Tuesday. — Following the shooting of Constables Craig and Burke, the cathedral town of Tuam went through a “perfect hell,” in the words of a resident, during the early hours of to-day. The police, having viewed the dead bodies of their comrades at the station, appear to have got completely out of hand. Fully armed they marched into the streets, smashed saloons, looting their contents, dragged young men out of bed and threatened to shoot them. Then they set fire to some of the most valuable properties in the township, causing damage to the extent of £100,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan E. Rice
title: Take the Next Step Toward Racial Justice
description: This incipient movement risks being reduced to a fleeting instant of heightened consciousness.
content: Since George Floyd’s murder, America has begun a remarkable reckoning with racial injustice. People of every race and generation have come together in largely peaceful protests across the nation to halt police brutality, which is disproportionately directed at people of color. But many Americans are demanding much more — that we finally redress the systemic racism that persists in this country, understanding that it diminishes us all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine Gunman Frees Captives After Documentary Demand Is Met
description: A man with a firearm and explosives took 13 hostages and demanded Ukraine’s president endorse a documentary about animal abuse. The president complied.
content: MOSCOW — A nearly 12-hour standoff in Ukraine between the police and an armed hostage-taker who demanded, among other things, that the country’s president publicly endorse a documentary about animal abuse ended with the man’s capture on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: The Virus Found a Crowded Houston Neighborhood, Sparing One Nearby
description: Two adjacent communities underscore the starkly divergent ways in which the coronavirus outbreak in Texas has attacked daily life.
content: HOUSTON — The starkly divergent ways in which the coronavirus has affected neighboring communities in the Houston area — one rich and one poor — underscore how it is a magnifier of inequities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Google’s virus-tracing apps can allow it to track some users’ locations.
description: When Google and Apple announced plans in April for free software to help alert people of their possible exposure to the coronavirus, the companies promoted it as “privacy preserving” and said it would not track users’ locations. Encouraged by those guarantees, Germany, Switzerland and other countries used the code to develop national virus alert apps that have been downloaded more than 20 million times.
content: When Google and Apple announced plans in April for free software to help alert people of their possible exposure to the coronavirus, the companies promoted it as “privacy preserving” and said it would not track users’ locations. Encouraged by those guarantees, Germany, Switzerland and other countries used the code to develop national virus alert apps that have been downloaded more than 20 million times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andre Andreev
title: There Is No Lonelier Job in Soccer Than This
description: For the Arsenal legend Bob Wilson, goalies must have “a desperate sense of courage.”
content: Is there any lonelier position in sports than goalie?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: N.Y. Subway, Facing a $16 Billion Deficit, Plans for Deep Cuts
description: The transit agency will announce budget cuts on Wednesday. Officials are hoping federal assistance will help ease the crisis that the pandemic has created.
content: Facing one of the biggest financial crises in the history of the subway, New York’s public transportation agency is preparing drastic measures to restore its finances that are likely to affect riders for years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: To Get People to Wear Masks, Look to Seatbelts, Helmets and Condoms
description: The ways we built habits around other routine safety measures can inform mask-wearing, experts say.
content: In the pediatric clinic where I worked for many years in Boston, each room held a clear plastic bowl full of brightly colored condoms. They were there on display, vivid and eye-catching, and part of my job — every provider’s job — was to offer them cheerfully and matter-of-factly and above all non-judgmentally to adolescents at every visit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times and Mason Trinca
title: Photos: Federal Forces Clash With Demonstrators in Portland
description: Thousands gathered downtown to protest as the conflict with law enforcement intensified overnight.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Conflicts between law enforcement and protesters intensified Monday night after the Trump administration deployed federal forces from an array of agencies to crack down on demonstrations, which began in response to the killing of George Floyd, and have extended for 54 consecutive days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Coronavirus Infections Much Higher Than Reported Cases in Parts of U.S., Study Shows
description: Data from antibody tests in 10 different cities and states indicate that many people with no symptoms may be spreading the virus.
content: The number of people infected with the coronavirus in different parts of the United States was anywhere from two to 13 times higher than the reported rates for those regions, according to data released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Who Is Behind Those N.B.A. ‘Bubble Life’ Tweets?
description: The @NBABubbleLife Twitter account has amassed more than 100,000 followers in less than two weeks with quirky commentary on the social media posts of basketball’s biggest stars.
content: For nearly two weeks, the Twitter accounts @NBABubbleLife and @WNBABubbleLife have anonymously chronicled the world’s best basketball players shotgunning beers, dancing with their teammates, failing at fishing and going about everyday activities, like getting haircuts and eating pancakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: High Voter Turnout and Record Fund-Raising Give Democrats Hope for November
description: Despite a disjointed primary season and the challenges of holding elections during a pandemic, the party is seeing a surge in energy among voters.
content: It has been one of the most challenging election years in a century: A deadly pandemic upended normal voting in state-by-state primaries, and a rapid expansion of mail-in ballots struggled to meet demand — problems exacerbated by the decades-long hollowing out of the Voting Rights Act and new, Republican-backed lawsuits to restrict ballot access.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Maazel
title: An Unidentifiable Stranger Plunges a Community Into Crisis in ‘Pew’
description: The new novel by Catherine Lacey features a narrator of no discernible gender, race or past and a Christian town whose tolerant posture is sorely tested.
content: PEWBy Catherine Lacey
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Trump’s Briefings, ‘The Apprentice’ and the Perils of the Second Season
description: President Trump seems to think there’s no such thing as too much of him on TV. He’s been wrong about that before.
content: The pinnacle of Donald J. Trump’s TV career lasted one night, and he has never stopped trying to relive it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Trump Campaign Ads Depict His Own Lawless Dystopia
description: For the past three weeks, the Trump campaign has been spending tens of millions of dollars on ads depicting a protest movement out of control, both to stoke fear among his base and rationalize his deployment decisions.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Raring to Go
description: It’s great to see Zhouqin Burnikel back in the race again.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — I was taught in school that, when it came to math, there could only be a single answer to a given problem. There might be different ways to get to that answer, but one answer there would be. That was supposed to be the good thing about numbers, the very thing that attracted people who like one answer per problem to the science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta and Veronica Penney
title: Big Tech Has a Big Climate Problem. Now, It’s Being Forced to Clean Up.
description: Apple said on Tuesday its devices would be carbon-neutral by 2030, making it the latest tech giant to ramp up voluntary climate targets.
content: The titans of the tech industry like to think of themselves as solvers of big world problems, and, lately, they’re tripping over themselves to show that they are working to solve a problem for which they, too, are culpable: climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Baker
title: Did America Use Bioweapons in Korea? Nicholson Baker Tried to Find Out
description: “Baseless,” the novelist’s new work of nonfiction, is the record of a frustrated investigation and an indictment of government secrecy.
content: BASELESSMy Search for Secrets in the Ruins of the Freedom of Information ActBy Nicholson Baker
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Amy Qin
title: China Uses W.H.O. Inquiry to Tout Coronavirus Response
description: The global health agency sent two experts to China, but it is unclear how much access they are getting. They must first complete a two-week quarantine.
content: Chinese officials are hailing a visit by a team of experts sent to Beijing by the World Health Organization to investigate the source of the coronavirus as evidence that the country is a responsible and transparent global power. But the investigation by the W.H.O. is likely to take many months and could face delays.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump, in a Departure, Says Virus Will Get Worse
description: More than 20,000 members of the U.S. military have contracted the virus, and the infection rate has soared recently. Major security flaws were found in a South Korean quarantine app.
content: President Trump abruptly departed on Tuesday from his rosy projections about the coronavirus, warning Americans from the White House briefing lectern that the illness would get worse before widespread recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Michael Bennett, a Protest Pioneer, Retires From the N.F.L.
description: The defensive end announced his retirement on Instagram after an 11-year career in which he won a Super Bowl with the Seattle Seahawks and became a leading voice on race and police brutality.
content: Michael Bennett, the standout defensive end who spoke out forcefully against racial injustice during his career, said he was retiring after an 11-year N.F.L. career, primarily with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Seattle Seahawks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Defying Trump, Lawmakers Move to Strip Military Bases of Confederate Names
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 22, 2020.
content: “You’re wrong — you need to change. We’re the party of Lincoln, the party of Emancipation; we’re not the party of Jim Crow. We should be on the right side of this issue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: I Spoke to Anthony Fauci. He Says His Inbox Isn’t Pretty.
description: An interview with the man who has an important message for you, if he can get it out.
content: Americans may have lost faith in their most cherished institutions — the presidency, Congress, the media, perhaps even democracy itself — but 65 percent of them still believe in Dr. Anthony Fauci.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: States Must Standardize Coronavirus Data, Former C.D.C. Director Says
description: Dr. Thomas Frieden proposed uniform reporting guidelines for states. Experts said the C.D.C. should have done it months ago.
content: As criticism of the Trump administration’s response to the coronavirus pandemic intensifies, a former director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Tuesday called on state health officials to start reporting coronavirus data in a detailed and uniform fashion, rather than the disorganized hodgepodge most states now produce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zoë Lescaze
title: 12 Artists On: The Financial Crisis
description: As the pandemic continues to derail the global economy, artists share works that reflect on uncertainty, capitalism and racial injustice.
content: The Covid-19 virus has sent the global economy spinning into a state of profound disturbance, casting the livelihoods of individuals and small businesses into doubt and leaving entire industries devastated. The financial impact of the pandemic on local communities, as cities and states slash budgets, and on the world at large will continue to play out in the months and years to come. For the fourth installment of our series T Agitprop, we asked 12 contemporary artists, including Torkwase Dyson, Tomashi Jackson, Isaac Julien and Agnieszka Kurant, to contribute works, most of them new and created exclusively for T, in response to this global emergency. Here are their pieces and statements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Lucas
title: The New York Times Has Shared a File With You
description: What happens when you invite staff members to make a Google Doc, write about what they’re thinking and doing during the pandemic, and make it public? “Notes From Our Homes to Yours” brings journalists and readers closer.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: In Alex Trebek’s Reluctant, Moving Memoir, Life Is All About the Next Question
description: The longtime “Jeopardy!” host writes about his struggle with pancreatic cancer in “The Answer Is...,” but saves most of the room for gratitude and enthusiasms.
content: Alex Trebek was a man in search of a vice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Trump’s Wag-the-Dog War
description: The president is looking for a dangerous domestic enemy to fight.
content: Some presidents, when they get into trouble before an election, try to “wag the dog” by starting a war abroad. Donald Trump seems ready to wag the dog by starting a war at home. Be afraid — he just might get his wish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Peisner
title: Concerts Aren’t Back. Livestreams Are Ubiquitous. Can They Do the Job?
description: With no return date for shows in sight, fans and artists are adapting to a new way of experiencing music together. Whether it’ll keep everyone satisfied — and paid — is still unclear.
content: On April 10, Phoebe Bridgers sat in her Los Angeles apartment in her pajamas, with a guitar across her lap and her head cocked quizzically to the side, staring into her phone’s camera. “I’ve never done this before,” the 25-year-old singer-songwriter said, strumming her Danelectro. “How are you guys? Is this, like, a normal angle? Is this good? Can you hear me?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: The Biases We Hold Against the Way People Speak
description: In “How You Say It,” Katherine Kinzler focuses on linguistic discrimination, how your accent can determine the way you are perceived.
content: HOW YOU SAY ITWhy You Talk the Way You Do — and What It Says About YouBy Katherine D. Kinzler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Paul Fusco, Photographer on a Funeral Train, Dies at 89
description: The pictures he took after Robert Kennedy’s assassination are among his many photographs that captured the human side of important events.
content: Paul Fusco, a photographer whose eye for the human impact of earthshaking events was perhaps never more evident than in the pictures he took of track-side mourners while riding Senator Robert F. Kennedy’s funeral train in 1968, died on July 15 at an assisted-living center in San Anselmo, Calif. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Say One Thing, Donate to Another
description: A new analysis shows how companies have funded political efforts that undermine their public stances.
content: Breaking: Carlyle announced this morning that one of its chief executives, Glenn Youngkin, will step down, leaving Kewsong Lee as the investment giant’s sole C.E.O. (Want this delivered to your inbox each day? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Worried About Crowded Planes? Know Where Your Airline Stands
description: Whether your flight will be jammed with passengers, or have enough empty seats to soothe virus-fearing travelers, really depends on the airline.
content: As air travel has ticked up in the last month, airlines have divided into two camps: those blocking strategic seats to offer more space, and those willing to fill planes to capacity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Works by Sir John Richardson’s Many Friends in Sotheby’s Sale
description: The art historian John Richardson collected art by his pals Pablo Picasso, Lucian Freud and Andy Warhol. The works will be sold in New York and London in the fall.
content: John Richardson, the art historian and Picasso biographer who died last year at 95, was a collector. He collected friends — Picasso, Georges Braque, Francis Bacon, Lucian Freud and Andy Warhol, to name only a few. He also collected images of friends, by friends. He had a portrait of Mick Jagger by Warhol and an etched self-portrait of Freud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Beware the ‘But China’ Excuses
description: Just because U.S. politicians and tech giants are blaming China, doesn’t mean we should be scared.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: That ‘Home Office’ of Yours? It Needs an Upgrade
description: You may be working from home for a while. It’s time for something more professional than a corner of the dining table.
content: If you’ve been working from home for months and have concluded that this situation is unlikely to end anytime soon, you may be giving your makeshift work space a serious second look. You’re not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: American corporations are bingeing on debt in the downturn.
description: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, American corporations have taken advantage of historically low interest rates to gorge themselves on debt. Then came the pandemic and the sharpest economic downturn in history, which resulted in an odd solution for the companies that did all that borrowing: more debt.
content: Since the 2008 global financial crisis, American corporations have taken advantage of historically low interest rates to gorge themselves on debt. Then came the pandemic and the sharpest economic downturn in history, which resulted in an odd solution for the companies that did all that borrowing: more debt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Shane Goldmacher and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden Announces $775 Billion Plan to Help Working Parents and Caregivers
description: In a speech in Delaware, Joseph R. Biden Jr. outlined proposals covering care for small children, older adults and family members with disabilities.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced a sweeping new $775 billion investment in caregiving programs on Tuesday, with a series of proposals covering care for small children, older adults and family members with disabilities. His campaign hopes the plan will land with particular resonance during a pandemic that has severely affected the caregiving needs of millions of American families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McGlynn
title: Quarantine and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
description: My 13-year-old son wasn’t engaged in online learning, but rebuilding an engine in the garage let him discover his “ferocious force.”
content: The morning after the governor of Wisconsin shut down schools in an effort to prevent the spread of Covid-19, my 13-year-old son, Hayden, gave himself a project. He would watch, in order of their release, every movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Starting with “Iron Man,” he worked his way through nearly two dozen movies in all. He finished in four and a half days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: 10 Best Quarantine Concerts Online
description: With in-person shows still mostly on hold, musicians are finding new ways to insert life into livestreams.
content: Some livestreamed concerts emulate the one-time-only experience of live shows — they’re webcast just once in real time, then disappear from the web. Others recognize that anything that’s digitized can be recorded and replayed. Here, alphabetically, are 10 of the best virtual concerts that have stayed online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Nicholas Fandos and Julian E. Barnes
title: Democrats Warn of Possible Foreign Disinformation Plot Targeting Congress
description: Democrats demanded an F.B.I. briefing. They were concerned about a potential Russian-linked effort to interfere in the election by using a Senate panel to advance smears against Joe Biden, officials said.
content: Top congressional Democrats warned in a cryptic letter they released on Monday that a foreign power was using disinformation to try to interfere in the presidential election and the activities of Congress, and demanded a prompt briefing by the F.B.I. to warn every member of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Plan to Revive Gotham Bar and Grill
description: The restaurant, which closed in March after 36 years, may be reborn if a deal from a former managing partner works out.
content: Gotham Bar and Grill, in business for 36 years and one of New York’s best-known restaurants, closed in March at the start of the pandemic lockdown. At the time, management said the situation was untenable, and that the closing was permanent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: ‘No One’ Protected British Democracy From Russia, U.K. Report Concludes
description: Russian efforts to interfere in the British political system were widely ignored by successive governments, according to a long-awaited report by Parliament.
content: LONDON — Russia has mounted a prolonged, sophisticated campaign to undermine Britain’s democracy and corrupt its politics, while successive British governments have looked the other way, according to a long-delayed report released on Tuesday by a British parliamentary committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Pompeo Praises Britain for Getting Tough on China
description: The secretary of state praised the British government for recent actions on China as the Trump administration tries to build a global coalition against Beijing.
content: LONDON — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Tuesday cheered the hardening British posture toward China and appealed for a global coalition against the country, blaming the Chinese Communist Party for what he described as exploitation of the coronavirus pandemic “to further its own interests.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Acitelli
title: Americans Hunker Down, Threatening the Self-Storage Industry
description: What once seemed like one of the few recession-proof parts of commercial real estate looks as vulnerable as many other businesses.
content: For years, the self-storage industry in the United States has relied on what insiders call the Four D’s: death, divorce, displacement and disaster. But the coronavirus pandemic, combined with aggressive competition and brash overexpansion, has made what once seemed like one of the few recession-proof parts of the commercial real estate industry look as vulnerable as many other businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Zizi Jeanmaire, French Star of Ballet, Cabaret and Film, Dies at 96

author: By Julia Felsenthal
title: The Rembrandt Self-Portrait That Has Long Captivated Pat Steir
description: When she lived in Amsterdam, the New York-based artist went to see this painting at least once a week.
content: Rembrandt van Rijn painted and etched his own image dozens of times over the course of his life, but it’s one of his earliest self-portraits, from around 1628, that haunts the New York artist Pat Steir. In this work, simply titled “Self-Portrait,” the 22-year-old Dutch master in the making renders himself in heavy chiaroscuro, his gaze obscured and light bouncing off his jaw to illuminate an earlobe and the edges of a helmet of frizzy hair. It’s an oddly dispassionate depiction. “He painted it the way he would paint a model, without personifying it,” observes Steir. “It’s letting go of imparting wisdom to the figure. Brilliance, scale, beauty — letting go of all that. That’s what’s hard to do.”
